reviewText:
Product received for free

Aurora Nights is a educative game about identifying constellations.
Your choice to have a help-line on or off. Nice artwork and sound.
The Mini encyclopedia is helpfull if you want to learn about the constellations mythes
The achievements makes it fun to try to get all the lines.

It costs 0.99 cents but is totally worth it.
voteText: 30 of 37 people (81%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I remember that when I was a kid, I enjoyed spending time looking at the sky and trying to figure out the constellations. Back then, I knew how to recognize only a couple of them and the others remained a complete mystery to me. Until I played this little game.

Aurora Nights is more of an educational software rather than a game, since there's no actual playthrough apart from connecting the dots representing the stars that compose each constellation. Of the 88 officially recognized constellations, the game teaches you how to recognize the 35 most common, in a very enjoyable and relaxing way. Additionally, for each group of stars you can read a small text explaining the origins of their name, most of these descending from Greek mythology.

In my opinion, the game is worth the price, for it's unique and interesting concept and I hope to see in the future an extension to the game, featuring the remaining 53 constellations.

More reviews on the Lilly's Corner Curator page
voteText: 24 of 27 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Product received for free

My videoreview about this game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iWyn3oCu46c

I quite liked the concept of this game since I wanted to be able to recognize constellations myself for quite some time now. This product is not really a game, it is more of a mnemonic tool in a setting with a nice atmosphere.

I have a few minor complaints about the game in its current state (as of the 26th of May 2016):
- The star map doesn't completely fit on the screen (at 1080p that is)
- A black band, saying ''constellation discovered covers constellations when completed
- There is a small mistake on the starmap for Canes Venatici (the hunting dogs), it shows three stars instead of two.

Overall, I really like the idea of this game and for 99 cents you can't really go wrong. Especially if you're interested in learning the basics of stargazing.

reviewText:
Aurora Nights is a game about discovering constellations as well as discovering some interesting facts and myths behind each constellation in the game. The game features 35 constellations, amongst those is Orion, a well-known Hunter, and Ursa Major.

The art style is beautiful. The concept for the game is unique and is interesting.

Things I consider to be a positive:

- The price
- Achievements
- Trading Cards
- Calimg soundtrack
- Good graphics
- Increased difficulty when you attempt the constellations

For action game players, it might not be interesting but for casual players, I feel it will be relaxing.

Do I recommend this game? I recommend this game to anyone who is interested in astronomy.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Some stars have a pattern which can be observed in the Earth's night sky. These group of stars are called asterisms and are part of one or more constellations. Aurora Nights is a game about discovering constellations by finding the pattern and link the stars.

Additionally, there is an encyclopedia section with some backstory of each (35) constellation. You can replay the same constellation to gain more information entries but the stars will be shuffled.

It's more like an educational game but can be difficult if you disable the lines that indicates how the pattern continues. Therefore, it can be easily beaten if you're interesting for the constellation facts only, yet hard if you're looking for some challenge.

---info---
A nice approach to learn constellations
Greek myth's all-over :P
Quiet ambient sound
Beatiful artwork but only one star-field background artwork
Aurora nights is the name but I didn't see much Aurora lights. :(

reviewText: Aurora Nights is more of an interactive encyclopedia than a game--everything takes place in two dimensions and on the same backdrop. However, it serves its purpose well, is relaxing, looks nice and has nice music and sound. There's around half an hour worth of 'gameplay' involved in unlocking all achievements. For a dollar, I can't complain. Recommended if you have any interest at all in constellations.

reviewText:
This review is purely subjective since I didn’t play any similar games before, so having no system of reference it is entirely based on my first run experience.

“Aurora Night” is a niche game, made with a special goal in mind. I did enjoy the experience and that says it all. If someone outside the scope of the game can enjoy it, then by all means it delivers and then some more.

In the end, one thing is sure, after this game when someone looks at the night sky will surely know what to look for!
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I purchased this a short time ago because right I could tell right away it was a great concept and a game of quality. There are plenty of free stellaiumesque programs online, but for the amateur astronomer (hell, anyone interested in learning the constellations), then I would highly recommend Aurora Nights.

The graphics are great, the music is beautiful, everything is executed in a very polished manner.

The devs are also wonderful. I had an issue on first start where my monitor was cropping the game wierdly and in a very short period of time, one of the devs voluntarily worked with me through chat to help resolve the issue (the details of which are on the forum if you're curious).

Great devs, great game, great music -- 10/10 would recommend, and furthermore it's only a dollar. You really only win buy purchasing this title.
